ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
SINGAPORE CITIZENS TAKING UP DUAL CITIZENSHIP


    1. Dr Lee Tsao Yuan asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether the Government allows Singapore citizens to take up dual citizenship, i.e. the citizenship of another country as well as that of Singapore's.

    The Minister of State for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government does not allow Singapore citizens to have dual citizenship.

    Singapore is a young nation. We have not reached the stage of nationhood where a Singaporean with a second citizenship would still retain his identity and loyalty to Singapore as his homeland wherever he goes, his second citizenship being only of secondary importance.

    Foreigners are granted Singapore citizenship only if they are committed to making Singapore their home, and see their long-term future with Singapore, in which case they should readily be prepared to give up their foreign nationality.

    Dr Lee Tsao Yuan (Nominated Member): Does the Minister of State envisage that there would be any policy change in the conceivable future?

    Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee: Sir, the answer is no.

    Mr Shriniwas Rai (Nominated Member): Would the Minister of State indicate to the House the countries in which Singapore citizens have acquired citizenship? And if the Government knows that they have acquired a foreign citizenship, what steps would the Government take to see that they either give up Singapore citizenship or the other country's citizenship, because I have known of countries where this has happened?

ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT



    Resumption of Debate on Question (26th February, 1999). "That Parliament approves the financial policy of the Government for the financial year 1st April, 1999 to 31st March, 2000.". - [Minister for Finance].

    Question again proposed.
12.34 pm

    Mr Lim Swee Say (Tanjong Pagar): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to support the motion standing in the name of Dr Richard Hu, Minister for Finance.

    Sir, the economic crisis we are going through today is the worst the world has seen in 50 years. Every economy is being put to a real test and they will come out with different responses. Take, for example, Hong Kong and Singapore. Even though both of us are among the world's

Column: 88

freest economies, yet we come out with very different responses. Just last week, the Hong Kong Secretary for Trade and Industry explained the different responses between Singapore and Hong Kong by saying that it was because the Singapore Government controls the people, the trade unions, and so on, whereas the Hong Kong people are more creative, more innovative. I have a different explanation. I think the core issue is that for the last 100 years, Hong Kong has been busy building a competitive economy, whereas in the case of Singapore, in the last 33 years, we have been busy building a nation.

    There is a big difference between building an economy and building a nation. In the case of Hong Kong, the focus is purely on competitiveness. In the case of Singapore, we adopt a balanced approach between competitiveness and cohesion. Because of this equal emphasis on competitiveness and cohesion, we are able to achieve unity in purpose, have a cohesive people and one united people. That is why we are able to move together in one force. Sir, there is a saying that people do not care how much the government knows until they know how much the government cares. If you were to look at the two off-Budget measures announced by the Minister and the Budget announced this year, if you look at the three Budgets in totality, it is quite clear that, firstly, this Government does know how to run the economy and the kind of difficulties the business community is facing. Hence these various cost-cutting measures. But more importantly, it also clearly demonstrated that the Government does care for the people knowing the kind of pain the people are going through as a result of wage reductions and so on. Therefore, the Government has introduced a total rebate amounting to about $485 million. It is a clear concrete action on the part of the Government to demonstrate that it knows how to run the economy and it cares for the people.

    Speaking as a labour MP, I fully support the financial policy announced by the Minister. Sir, this Budget 1999-2000 is a very significant one for two reasons, at least. Firstly, this will be the first time that

Column: 89

we are going to run into a significant operating deficit. Secondly, this is the Budget that will take us into the next century. I feel it is very important that we make full use of this Budget to spur Singaporeans to embrace a new mindset in preparation for the new millennium. To transform the mindset of the population, I think it is very much like trying to change the shape of a block of solid ice. One way to do it is, firstly, "de-freeze" the ice, because a solid block of ice is very hard to reshape. But if you can de-freeze the ice and reshape the water and then re-freeze the water, we can end up with a new mindset, like a new block of ice with a new shape, without losing too much water. Looking at the mindset of Singaporeans, over the last 33 years, we do form a certain mindset after all these years. And now this mindset of Singaporeans is de-freezing under the heat of the regional crisis. In a way, I think our challenge is to capitalise on this opportunity now to reshape the mindset of Singaporeans before this mindset is being re-frozen again. The next two to three years is really a window of opportunity for us to do so. Even though the cyclical recovery of the Singapore economy is likely to happen, maybe over the next six months to a year, structural recovery is not likely to take place until after a period of a few years of concerted effort by all parties. Therefore, it is very important that over this period of two to three years, we make full use of the financial policies to spur all Singaporeans, business community, civil servants towards a new mindset, so that we can move together in one force, in one united direction.

    In this regard, Sir, I feel that there are three areas we can do with more emphasis in the implementation of the financial policy this coming year. These three areas are the public sector, the private sector and the people sector. Firstly, in the public sector, I feel that 1999-2000 is a good time for us to forge a new mindset in the public sector among the civil servants. In the past, we have always looked at unspent budget as something bad because it adds further to budget surplus. But this year is different. We are going to have a budget deficit,

Column: 90

which means any Ministry that is able to save on the annual budget is, in fact, going to help us to reduce the budget deficit. So any unspent budget should be viewed as something good rather than bad. In fact, if the civil service can improve spending or achieve a saving of 1% alone, it will amount to about $292 million. It is a lot of money. If we are able to achieve a 5% improvement in cost optimisation, the total saving will come to $1.5 billion, which is about 30% of the budget deficit.

    Sir, my main point here is this. I am actually very comfortable with the $5.1 billion budget deficit, but my point is that I am not convinced that every civil servant is putting every dollar to the best use. We are putting the money to good use but not necessarily to the best use. My suggestion is why not send a clear message to all civil servants to take this year as a beginning of the new year to challenge ourselves on how we can, as a public sector, achieve better outcomes with lesser resources. And here I have two suggestions on how this can be done. Firstly, send a clear guideline to all Ministries to cut down on the "nice-to-have" spending on hardware facilities. Because I feel that over time, our hardware facilities, like the schools, hospitals, including bus stops, are getting better-looking year after year. There is a danger that we may have gone over board. Choosing between a public institution of a 5-star hardware facility and a 3-star software capability versus one with 5-star software capability and 3-star hardware facility, I think any time I will go for the one that is able to offer 5-star software capability because this software capability is what will make a difference in the quality of public services to the members of the public. By making a constant check on cost control on hardware spending, hopefully, we would be able to reduce the cost of public services to the members of the public.

    My suggestion is that as far as the hardware design and hardware spending are concerned, let us remind ourselves that we must continue to focus on functionality, buildability, maintainability, and so on. Better still, why not set cost standards and challenge the Ministries to try

Column: 91

to achieve saving over the next few years? At the same time, we have to challenge the Ministries to set clear targets on how they can improve on software capability. Today we already have the Budgeting For Results system in place. Why not we require all Ministries now to clearly spell out exactly what kind of software capability targets they are going to achieve over the next few years. Hopefully, by re-orientating our focus on software capability, making a check on hardware spending, we would be able to offer better public services at lower cost.

    My second suggestion is that in the coming years, can we not do something to encourage inter-Ministry collaboration and innovation in the public sector? We are going to face many new economic and social challenges in the coming years and many of them will be very different from the kind of challenges we had faced in the past. Take, for example, from an economic angle, our challenge to move towards a knowledge-based economy. So many Ministries will have to be involved, whether it is MTI, MOM, Education, and so on and so forth.

    On the social front, our challenge is to overcome such issues as aging population and the emergence of an information society. Again, many Ministries will have to be involved in order to make sure that the social need, economic issues and so on of an aging population are addressed. The Inter-Ministry Committee on the Aged is a step in the right direction. We have to do likewise for the information society.

    From the nation-building point of view, we also have new challenges, like the one being addressed by the Singapore 21 Committee, chaired by RAdm Teo Chee Hean, regarding the strengthening of the heartware of Singaporeans. Again, many Ministries have to be involved if we want to truly make a quantum leap in strengthening the heartware in the population.

    Sir, my point here is that be it knowledge-based economy or information society or aged population or strengthening the heartware of Singaporeans,

Column: 92

all these are multi-dimensional issues requiring inter-Ministry collaboration, over a sustained period of time. If we want to really achieve the kind of outcome we are looking for, we will need to set clear targets, assign clear responsibility and support them with adequate resources. In other words, we may have to look into ways of creating a separate budget for such inter-Ministry projects and, hopefully, this new budget will not be created at the expense of increasing our budget deficit. My suggestion is to reduce all Ministries' budget by 10%. With that, we will be able to create a fund of about $3 billion. Put this fund under the direct charge of the Ministry of Finance and use it to support inter-Ministry projects and collaboration so that, over time, the issue of knowledge economy, information society, and so on, can really be addressed in a concerted effort by all Ministries and all civil servants.

    Secondly, I feel that there is also a need to strengthen the new mindset in the private sector. Up till now, we have often heard the business community complaining that the cost of doing business in Singapore is too high and that we need to lower cost. But how low can we go? At the end of the day, what is the purpose of economic progress if we keep on talking about cost cutting, wage cutting, and so on? Over time, I am not too sure how we can sustain our competitiveness through cost cutting. It is quite clear that innovation and adaptability are really the key if we want to sustain our growth in a knowledge-based economy. But we have to recognise that process towards a knowledge-based economy is going to be an evolutionary approach and the process will take time. The change management expert will tell us that any change process would go through at least five stages. We start with the pioneers, the early adopters, the early majority, followed by the late majority and then the laggard.

    The challenge for Singapore is not to try to achieve the change overnight but rather how we can speed up this evolutionary approach. How can we help the early adopters and pioneers to succeed in setting the pace so that, hopefully, they

Column: 93

will give encouragement to many more others to come along? In this regard, I feel that the off-Budget measures last year and the Budget this year have sent a very clear message only to the financial community. The feedback from the business community is that they are not hearing the same strong message being sent to all the other sectors, whether it is manufacturing or retail or communication, and so on. So my suggestion is this. Why not revise all the incentive packages managed by all the economic agencies to encourage companies to move towards knowledge-based companies?

    In this regard, I have two suggestions. For companies to be knowledge-based companies, firstly, they must be able to develop total capabilities, hopefully base their operations in Singapore. We have to encourage them to deepen their capabilities in individual areas, whether it is technology development, market development, innovation development, organisation development or mass customisation. In each of these areas, obviously we have to encourage them to deepen their capabilities. But what is even more important is to encourage them to nurture their capabilities in all these five areas so that they will be able to function truly as knowledge-based companies to be able to respond quickly to market changes and conditions.

    Sir, I feel that the existing incentive schemes in Singapore today are basically targeted at individual capabilities. Maybe it is about time that the Ministry of Finance reviewed the need on whether we should repackage all these incentive schemes so that, while on the one hand, we achieve the deepening of capability objective but, at the same time, we achieve the broadening capability objective. Maybe we should also look into whether there is a need to reorganise the duties and responsibilities of various economic agencies because it is no longer possible for each of the economic agencies to promote their own areas of interest in isolation. Take, for example, for any company which wants to be a knowledge-based company, henceforth, when they want to deepen their R&D

Column: 94

capability, they talk to NSTB. When they want to enhance their innovation capability, they talk to NCB and EDB. When they want to go into mass customisation, they talk to EDB and JTC. When they want to go to market development, they talk to TDB. When they want to go to organisation development, they talk to MOM. Over time, if we continue to let this develop, we are going to lose our capability in offering one-stop service to these leading investors of the world, whether they are MNCs or local enterprises. So I hope that this is something that the Government would think about.

    The second area, in promoting the change of mindset in the private sector is that, for knowledge-based companies to succeed, for them to have this total capability, obviously they have to invest more in manpower development. If I were to be objective about this, today, there are three ways at least a knowledge-based company can develop their manpower. The first is by retraining their existing workforce. The second is by getting rid of those who cannot fit in and recruit young Singaporeans who are better educated. The third is to recruit foreign talents. I think all three approaches are equally relevant. But my point is that, from the company's point of view, the cost of redeveloping the existing workforce is most time-consuming and, in fact, can be most expensive. Therefore, it is very important that we do something to help them to balance the cost equation so that it will make business sense for companies to reinvest in manpower rather than to displace them with younger or foreign talents.

    Sir, I feel that what we have to do is to set up a manpower development assistance scheme. When we decided to promote R&D, we have the Research Development Assistance Scheme (RDAS). When we promote innovation, we have the Information Development Scheme (IDS). When we want to promote market development, we have the Market Development Assistance Scheme (MDAS). Today, we want to promote manpower development, why not set up a Manpower Development Assistance Scheme so that

Column: 95

all companies will find it to their commercial interest to invest in manpower development. Hopefully, over time, the training and development of knowledge workers will become a joint responsibility of not just the Government and the union but all companies as well.

    Sir, let me move on to the third area, which is the people sector. Likewise, we need to find ways to inculcate a new mindset in the people sector as well. We are going to face a lot of new challenges in the area of social cohesion as we move ahead. In the past, when we talked about social cohesion, we focused on areas like, for example, racial harmony, wealth sharing, and so on. But, in future, there will be new issues that would challenge us in terms of social cohesion. Take, for example, the potential widening of social gap between the young and the old; the widening of wage gap between the knowledge workers and the unskilled workers; and the widening of communication gap between the connected and the unconnected in the population. The greater inflow of foreign talents and the increasing number of structurally unemployable Singaporeans will add to social tension as well.

    Sir, the question is: what can we do to further strengthen this greater sense of caring and sharing in the age of globalisation and technology? I remember that in the past, when we wanted to change the mindset of Singaporeans towards family planning, when we wanted them to go beyond two, to go for three or four if they could afford it, what did we do? We offered them a whole host of incentives like priority in school registration. We even offered them tax rebate amounting to $20,000. In fact, many people said that you could actually start a bigger family to enjoy pioneer status for four to five years, and so on. Now the question is: at a time like this, when we are going to encounter many more social challenges, why not consider to provide some kind of incentives to encourage and reinforce some of these social values which will help us to strengthen our social cohesion in the

Column: 96

future? Take, for example, this year, we are going to give a 10% tax rebate to all taxpayers. My question is: why not just give 5% rebate to everyone? For the other 5% equivalent, we can return it to the taxpayer, for example, in the form of higher tax relief for parents and dependants. So, hopefully, this will help to send across the message that the family is a very important building block of society.

    Another example. We want to encourage people to continue to contribute to charity and community projects. Why not give them tax allowance just like the way we give investment allowance to companies who invest in capital equipment? The difference between a company investing in capital equipment versus somebody who gives money to charity is, in my view, that one is investing for economic return, whereas when giving to charity, we are investing for social return, ie, social cohesion. I think both are worth supporting.

    Sir, these are just some of the suggestions. My point basically is that we can think about how to use all these taxation incentives, rebates, and so on, to also help reshape the mindset of Singaporeans so that they will be more aware of the need to take on a greater sense of social responsibility as we move ahead.

    Sir, in conclusion, 1999 is a golden opportunity for us to inculcate a new mindset in all the three "P" sectors - the Public sector, the People sector and the Private sector. We need to inculcate this new mindset because, for Singapore to succeed, we need to have many more new change agents in the Government, the business community and the people sector, so that the pace of change will be faster. It is my hope that, in the implementation of this year's financial policy, we will send a very clear signal to all Singaporeans and the business community that only by constantly reinventing our economy, our society and our civil service, can we become even more competitive as a knowledge economy, more cohesive as an information society and more united as a developed nation in the 21st century.

Column: 97



    Mrs Lim Hwee Hua (Marine Parade): Mr Speaker, Sir, for those of us who have visited New York City, we may have come across the display of "The National Debt Clock" on a wall near 42nd Street in midtown. Amongst other things, it tells the American people how big the country's interest burden is. Apparently, this clock serves as a stern warning against wasteful Government spending.

    Over here in Singapore, the Government is expecting to record a budget deficit of some $5 billion for the financial year beginning 1st April 1999 which is almost 11 times the projected deficit of $466 million for the current financial year.

    The last time Singapore recorded a budget deficit was during the downturn in the mid-80s. Since then, we have booked in a surplus averaging more than $4 billion a year, reaping the full benefits of the boom cycle between 1994 and 1996. This has enabled us to take a definitive step forward towards further development of capabilities.

    Sir, the two successive years of budget deficits should not be taken lightly. And we note that they are not the result of wasteful Government spending. Neither are they the result of a bailing out of the corporate or banking sector but of carefully planned expenditure to help position Singapore for further growth beyond the crisis.

    Investors and Singaporeans alike would have noted that the cumulative deficits for FY98 and FY99 will draw down the bulk of the FY97 reserves, which have provided adequate cushion for pushing ahead with long-term plans on the one hand and extending short-term assistance during this crisis on the other. As a result, I do not think investors are asking how we are going to fund these deficits.

    The planned 10% jump in development expenditure to $13.9 billion is the strongest demonstration of a commitment towards building economic capabilities in spite of the current regional crisis. In the context of a depressed economic region, this is quite a luxury.

Column: 98



    Sir, this crisis has triggered many structural changes within the region, not least within Singapore, and within the financial sector. Many big corporations have undertaken massive restructuring towards becoming leaner and meaner organisations. In the process, many have no choice but to divest non-core businesses or write off substantial sums.

    Deserving businesses caught in a credit crunch have been acquired by investors frequently of foreign origin. There is a quest towards streamlining operations for better economies of scale or towards strengthening capitalisation to better position for a fast-changing economic landscape. These have inspired several mergers of corporations.

    The Monetary Authority of Singapore is spearheading a bold, but necessary, blueprint for changes to the financial sector in Singapore. We aim ultimately to be a financial hub that involves major players offering a whole gamut of financial services. This has already spurred the merging of several banks. There is no doubt that the ensuing consolidation of strength will facilitate the capturing of a bigger role in domestic and regional banking.

    Sir, I would now like to focus on the implications of some of these changes, particularly for the small and medium enterprises (or SMEs) in the short-term, and entrepreneurship in the longer term.

    As banks consolidate and streamline efficiencies, in the current climate, there may be a tendency to move in favour of servicing the bigger customers. No doubt, some banks have actually defined the middle market as a niche segment but it is highly conceivable that smaller companies may wind up being under-served or poorly-served by the restructured banking system.

    Currently, the SMEs are already feeling the heat of a cashflow squeeze brought about by a credit crunch. Many are lamenting the tight, if not fast disappearing, credit terms. Whilst we can logically expect banks to exercise prudence at this time, so as to minimise the level of non-performing loans, many SMEs are

Column: 99

concerned that given the massive restructuring, their traditional bankers may have abandoned them altogether.

    Sir, perhaps some of these fears may be exaggerated but this raises an important question. Is it time to revisit the need to provide some form of development financing, similar to the role played by the Development Bank of Singapore in our formative years of growth? Although various assistance schemes exist, they tend to cater mainly to manufacturing of electronics or technology.

    Entrepreneurship frequently gets tripped up by a lack of funds. Beyond exploring the question of a sustenance of the traditional bank credit or availability of development and financing, more needs to be done.

    Sir, in Singapore, multi-national corporations have hitherto been a substantial employer, often offering challenging jobs on attractive terms. This has reinforced the tendency amongst Singaporeans towards being an employee rather than an entrepreneur or a shareholder.     Sir, in this connection too, I urge that the training allowance for older workers at $500 could be reviewed, because it is very difficult to encourage workers to go into training if the allowances are marginal and are not attractive enough to sustain them. Sir, the next group of people who deserve attention are the pensioners who draw very low pension of less than $200. Monthly pensions of less than $200 might make it difficult for them to manage under trying times. I see that these pensioners are stretched, if they have no other means of support. They are, in fact, no better than those who are on public assistance. Sir, surely this group of pensioners deserves a better deal as they have given sterling services to the Government and many of them served their best for over 30 years. I see that there is justification for a base-up revision of their pensions to meet at least a minimum requirement for their living. These low income pensioners deserve a review - I have been making pleas on their behalf over the years - and I hope that this will touch the Finance Minister's heart and he would be able to do something for them.

    Sir, another group is the 1- and 2-room families who have been given PUB rebates from $50 to $100. Many of these people are in seasonal employment and they are also hit by the economic recession. Column: 173

be standardised to $200. This, I think, will help to alleviate some of their problems.

    The last group which requires our attention is those families which have to look after their aged sick parents. I am glad that the Ministry of Health is planning to subsidise these families. However, this move would not be able to reduce the burden of those families in the sandwich income group who faces financial burden in the increasing cost of nursing care. The number of families with aged sick parents will increase steeply in the near future. In this case, we have to try and find ways in which we could relieve the burden through more tax rebates, so that their aged sick parents need not be institutionalised.     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon (Bukit Timah)(In Mandarin): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the Budget announced by the Finance Minister this year has not drawn much reaction from our people because last year the Government had already announced packages to deal with the currency and economic crisis. More importantly, whenever the Government makes any important decision, they would first communicate with the people so that they could be psychologically prepared for it.

    Undoubtedly, this Budget has basically looked after the needs of our people in this time of crisis. According to some of our workers, many seminars or talks were conducted over the past one to two years,

Column: 174

and they are aware that the Government has been planning for their future.

    Our workers are concerned with more long-term issues. From the feedback we have received, it appears that our workers want the Government to provide them with more opportunities to acquire the necessary skills to cope with the challenges ahead as we are evolving into a knowledge-based economy.

Looking at the future, would it not be better if we have a centralised authority to take charge of the overall planning and implementation of the national IT policies?

    Why do we have to actively and strenuously promote IT technology? We need to do so because this will give us a leading edge in a knowledge economy. Column: 175

people. When we have more people using IT, productivity will go up. For example, engineers or doctors could use 3-D imaging to more accurately and quickly make diagnosis and decisions.

    Now, e-commerce has become a new mode of business transactions. With more people possessing IT skills, they will be able to work smarter and faster. With more people possessing IT skills, their employability will be better and productivity of the various companies and factories would go up.     As for the non-professionals, they are the people with potential economic values. Our housewives have helped us to manage warm homes for the families, and to pass on our traditional values to the next generation. Perhaps, we should set up an unprecedented target of 80% of our families owning computers in three years' time.

Column: 177

commercial buildings are being rebuilt as intelligent buildings. HDB may perhaps try a pioneer scheme to design some intelligent-type flats conducive to the application of computers at home.

We must let everybody possess the skills to use computers so that they could more effectively participate in all these IT activities.

Column: 178

website within three seconds. With more people accessing the Singapore websites, the status of our nation will also go up and our economy will be stronger.     We all know that the Ministry of Education, MOM, MTI, MITA, Ministry of Communications, MND, are all developing their own plans to promote the use of IT. I feel very strongly that we should have a Ministry to coordinate all these activities. At the moment, every Ministry is carrying out activities to develop their IT applications, using the guidelines issued by NCB. However, there should be more practical guidelines to keep abreast of the times. For example, I know of a civil servant who took his children to Funan Centre to buy a Pentium III. Column: 179

extinct in Funan Centre, but this 486 is still very much alive on the office desk of this poor civil servant. This is no good. We should have some plans to upgrade and replace our computers in the Government offices.

    Our computer is no longer just a computer. It is a bridge or a window for our people to have a lifelong learning process or it may even set new policy and direction. We should set a target of, say, once in every three years, we must replace the computers in our Government offices. Although this may incur some heavy expenditure, it just cannot be helped.

    If we have a centralised Ministry to be overall in charge and coordinate the replacement of computers in all the Government departments, community clubs, community centres and the People's Association, our civil servants and public officers will have their computers replaced, from time to time, with the latest models and the best capabilities available, it would certainly enhance their productivity.

Five years from now, when almost every family has a computer at home, the CCs and RCs should equip themselves with more high-end computers that an ordinary family could not afford. Only then can we attract a new generation of residents to come forward and make use of the latest technology. Column: 180

survival, should we not upgrade NCB, TAS, SBA, etc;, related organisations, to become a centralised ministry like a Ministry of IT Power to be overall in charge of all aspects of IT applications in Singapore? I hope my suggestions would be seriously considered by the Minister for Finance.

    Mr Hawazi Daipi (Sembawang): Mr Deputy Speaker, at no other time than in the midst of an economic crisis do we feel most strongly the bond of citizenship that ties us together as one community, one nation, as Singaporeans. Through the economic and political uncertainties in the region, hardship due to retrenchments and reduction in income, and the sheer grit to be on top of the challenges and to stay ahead of our competitors, I believe Singaporeans have become closer together. While the feeling is that the people have become closer to the Government, their expectation of the Government has also grown. We begin to demand much more from the Government than we did when the economy was booming and growing, when times were good. So, in good times people expect a lot from the Government, and in bad times, perhaps a lot more. Perhaps this is expected of a good Government, which means so much more to the people in adversity.

    And the Government has indeed come through with several schemes and programmes to assist those in economic difficulty - to help our people deal with the difficult situation. These schemes and programmes comprise outright assistance to individuals as well as indirect assistance to keep businesses alive in Singapore, through incentives and tax cuts. For businesses, they are structurally well able to take advantage of the different Government programmes, some to maintain an existence until good times come again, while others take the opportunity to grow and generate more business.

    Sir, it has not escaped the people that this Government cares for them. The tax rebate and the rebate on service and conservancy charges are cases in point. They are really important at a time when

Column: 181

our workers have sacrificed in terms of wage and CPF cuts. The HDB heartlanders who may not pay income tax or pay little of it, I believe, do appreciate the rebate on conservancy charges.

    I do agree with the Prime Minister and some speakers before me that we must help and take care of each other in times of difficulties. To start with, the social safety net in Singapore has been excellent. No one has been forced to be on the street when he is out of employment as the HDB allows mortgage repayment scheme that is sympathetic to them. The children of such workers would also not have to leave school as there are assistance schemes for them to pay their school fees. Those who fall sick and really cannot pay their hospitalisation bills, they too have not been turned away just because they cannot afford it. For individuals, especially the sole breadwinners affected by the economic crisis, ie, those who have been retrenched, forced into bankruptcy or those who have had their salaries reduced, a comprehensive scheme of referral and help would assist them to overcome the tremendous psychological impact of these difficult times.

    Again, there are several different programmes devised by the Government or community organisations, but the individual in despair is usually likely not to know where or how to begin. To be more effective, organisations like the CDCs could create a one-stop centre with trained officers to advise and counsel those adversely affected by the economic crisis, steering them towards Government and community programmes which are available and suitable for their needs. These officers could then cater to the individual's specific needs as such a person has certain problems which are particular and peculiar to him or her. For union members, there are less problems as our network of unions has schemes to help members find alternative jobs and render relief assistance to the retrenched. But only about a quarter of our workers are union members, and in the larger context, we should help our fellow Singaporeans in a more coordinated way.

Column: 182



    In our vision of a caring society, we need more than just the solutions to an individual's predicament. We also need to provide the "doctor" who will bridge the gap between the "disease" and the "medicine". We need a systemic approach to the situation rather than the laudable but ad-hoc actions. We should have officers in agencies like the CDCs, officers with the heart in the right places, to guide and advise fellow Singaporeans who have lost their jobs and are facing difficulties.

    In an employers' market, the individual is helpless in the face of discrimination. Discrimination, be it along the line of race, gender or age, can become the root of contradiction to the bonds of citizenship that I spoke about earlier. When employers fall to temptation and take advantage of the present crisis to satisfy their prejudices against specific sectors of people, then Singapore as a nation becomes a sham. That is not what we aspire for Singapore. Luckily, this is not a widespread practice. I do not think that we are seeing the worsening of this situation. But when jobs are more scarce and the retrenched take more time to get alternative jobs, such form of discrimination becomes more glaring. The question before us then is: should we legislate against discrimination as in the United States?

    I would argue against this. We do have in place instruments to counter outright prejudices, like the Presidential Council for Minority Rights. Legislation to implement the kinds of laws that enforce equal opportunity can be damaging to race relations which is already a sensitive issue in a multi-ethnic nation like Singapore. This kind of legislation can lead to the polarisation of society through confrontation as it dictates the correct responses with the likely result of anger and cynicism. The better path would be education and persuasion, that it is in the best interest of our society and our nation when there is respect for age, for women, for those who are handicapped and for people of other races. This can and should be taught, especially in a still developing, young society like Singapore. I am glad that Government leaders like Deputy Prime Minister, Dr Tony Tan, have spoken

Column: 183

against discriminatory practices at workplaces. We must send the right signals that discrimination along the line of age, gender or race is also not acceptable.

    Singaporeans must be provided with the necessary education and training to see that discrimination in any form is detrimental to the refinement of our society. We should make it even more possible for Singaporeans of different racial groups and social status to work with and support each other. Our self-help organisations should be provided with the incentives to open the doors of their services to members of other ethnic groups.

    Sir, I think we should also try to ensure that what I consider as `manpower leakage' is reduced. I am talking about drop-outs from our education system. Over the years, our education system is designed to ensure that all young Singaporeans obtain a good basic education and skills training. At a time when we are worried about the vulnerability of our older workers to the structural changes of our economy, we cannot afford to see our young people wasting the educational and training opportunities open to them in our schools and institutions. Instead, we should push towards greater value-added performances by students and schools.

    Sir, allow me to go back to a point I made earlier about how people expect so much from the Government, both in good and bad times. At a time when we are talking about re-skilling our workers, instead of giving outright rebates, should not the Government consider giving away the goodies in the form that can be used for skills training by our workers? In short, we should re-visit the idea of "skillsave" for workers along the same line that we give Edusave to our students.

Column: 184



    Sir, NMP Mr Gerard Ee had earlier said that while we help our people prepare for the future challenges, we must not lose sight of their current difficulties. I would like to take a look at the other side of the coin. The point I am making is that while we earnestly help the needy in these times of difficulties, we must not lose sight of the long-term problems and challenges facing our economy. We must help our old and young Singaporeans to re-tool themselves with the skills that are relevant for the future. This is in their own interest and in the interest of our nation.

    In conclusion, the raising of these issues is fundamental to the kind of society we wish to progress towards. It is perhaps the silver lining in the economic recession that we are faced with today when such issues come into sharper focus and we realise the need to address them to advance.
